notes.title: Cornell Notes - Speech Outline
notes.content:
Title: Public Speaking Preparation

Question/Keyword
- Main idea: audience analysis

Notes
- Intro: Hook + thesis
- Body: 3 main points w/ examples
- Conclusion: summary + call to action

Summary
- Audience-centered preparation helps clarity

notes.title: Communication Models Overview
notes.content:
Main Idea: Communication is the process of sharing information between individuals.

Detail 1:
- Linear Model: One-way communication
- Interactive Model: Two-way with feedback
- Transactional Model: Simultaneous exchange

Detail 2:
- Verbal vs Non-verbal communication
- Barriers to effective communication

Detail 3:
- Importance in academic and professional settings

Summary:
- Understanding models helps improve communication skills

notes.title: Public Speaking Preparation
notes.content:
Who:
- Speaker (me)
- Audience (classmates/professor)

What:
- Topic: Effective communication strategies
- Purpose: Educate and engage

When:
- Date: Next class session
- Time: 30 minutes

Where:
- Classroom setting
- Online platform

Why:
- To improve presentation skills
- Required for course

How:
- Research topic thoroughly
- Practice delivery
- Use visual aids

notes.title: Polya's 4 Steps - Practice Problem
notes.content:
1. Understand the Problem:
- Identify audience constraints

2. Devise a Plan:
- Structure into intro, problem examples, takeaways

3. Carry Out the Plan:
- Draft 30 minute talk, rehearse

4. Look Back:
- Collect feedback

notes.title: Self-Concept Development
notes.content:
Definition:
- Self-concept is how we perceive ourselves

Characteristics:
- Shaped by experiences
- Influences behavior
- Can be positive or negative

Examples:
- Academic self-concept
- Social self-concept

Non-Examples:
- Physical appearance only
- Temporary moods

notes.title: Main Idea & Details - Identity
notes.content:
Main Idea: Self-concept is shaped by experiences.

Detail 1:
- Family, peers

Detail 2:
- Academic performance

Detail 3:
- Online persona

Summary:
- Multiple influences shape self-concept

notes.title: Personal Growth Plan
notes.content:
Week: Week 1

Goals:
- Improve time management
- Build self-confidence
- Learn new skills

Tasks:
- Daily planning routine
- Weekly reflection
- Skill practice sessions

notes.title: Fitness Components
notes.content:
Main Idea: Physical fitness has multiple components that work together.

Detail 1:
- Cardiovascular endurance
- Muscular strength
- Muscular endurance

Detail 2:
- Flexibility
- Body composition
- Skill-related fitness

Detail 3:
- Importance of balance
- Regular assessment needed

Summary:
- Holistic approach to fitness required

notes.title: Exercise Planning
notes.content:
Week: Fitness Week 1

Goals:
- Improve cardiovascular health
- Build muscle strength
- Increase flexibility

Tasks:
- 30 min cardio 3x/week
- Strength training 2x/week
- Stretching routine daily

notes.title: Quiz
notes.content: Module 6 and 7

notes.title: Polya's 4 Steps - Exercise Plan
notes.content:
1. Understand the Problem:
- Need balanced fitness plan

2. Devise a Plan:
- Mix cardio, strength, flexibility

3. Carry Out the Plan:
- Schedule and measure

4. Look Back:
- Adjust intensity

notes.title: Problem Solving with Math
notes.content:
1. Understand the Problem:
- Read carefully
- Identify known/unknown
- Draw diagram if helpful

2. Devise a Plan:
- Choose appropriate method
- Consider multiple approaches

3. Carry Out the Plan:
- Execute calculations
- Check work

4. Look Back:
- Verify solution
- Consider alternative methods
- Reflect on process

notes.title: 5W1H - Word Problems
notes.content:
Who:
- Students

What:
- Solve word problems

When:
- During class practice

Where:
- Worksheets, exams

Why:
- Develop reasoning

How:
- Identify variables, set equations

notes.title: Mathematical Concepts in Daily Life
notes.content:
Central Concept:
- Mathematics

Related Concept 1:
- Statistics (data analysis)

Related Concept 2:
- Probability (uncertainty)

Connections:
- Used in decision making
- Essential for modern careers
- Foundation for technology

notes.title: Python Variables and Data Types
notes.content:
Definition:
- Variables store data values

Characteristics:
- Dynamic typing
- Case-sensitive
- Can change type

Examples:
- x = 5 (integer)
- name = "John" (string)

Non-Examples:
- Starting with numbers
- Using reserved keywords

notes.title: Programming Project Planning
notes.content:
Week: Project Week 1

Goals:
- Learn Python basics
- Complete first assignment
- Understand debugging

Tasks:
- Study variables and loops
- Write sample programs
- Test and debug code

notes.title: Frayer - Variables
notes.content:
Definition:
- Variables store values

Characteristics:
- Mutable, named, typed

Examples:
- x = 5

Non-Examples:
- 5x (invalid)

notes.title: Computer Systems Overview
notes.content:
Main Idea: Computer systems consist of hardware and software working together.

Detail 1:
- Hardware components
- Input/output devices
- Storage systems

Detail 2:
- Operating systems
- Application software
- System software

Detail 3:
- Network connectivity
- Security considerations

Summary:
- Understanding components enables better use

notes.title: Computing Ethics Discussion
notes.content:
Who:
- Students and instructor
- Technology users

What:
- Digital responsibility
- Privacy concerns

When:
- Throughout the course
- In assignments

Where:
- Classroom discussions
- Online forums

Why:
- Prevent misuse
- Promote responsible computing

How:
- Follow codes of conduct
- Respect intellectual property
- Protect personal data

notes.title: Concept Map - Systems
notes.content:

- Computer Systems

Related Concept 1:
- Hardware

Related Concept 2:
- Software

Connections:
- OS manages hardware and software

notes.title: Computing Ethics Overview
notes.content:
Main Idea: Ethics guide professional behavior in computing.

Detail 1:
- Privacy concerns

Detail 2:
- Responsibility in AI

Summary:
- Ethical guidelines protect users

notes.title: Concept Map - Ethics
notes.content:
Central Concept:
- Computing Ethics

Related Concept 1:
- Privacy

Related Concept 2:
- Bias in AI

Connections:
- Policy and design decisions

quotes: Everyday is a new day for a wise man.
The only way to do great work is to love what you do. — Steve Jobs
Tell me and I forget. Teach me and I remember. Involve me and I learn. — Benjamin Franklin
Practice doesn't make perfect. Practice makes permanent. — Unknown
Strive for progress, not perfection. — Unknown
We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit. — Aristotle
If you want to change the world, change education.
